awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Realizing Visual and Acoustic Near Field Communication Systems for Smartphones: Performance Optimization and Security Assurance
awd_abstract_narration:
Near-Field Communication (NFC) is an emerging wireless technology that expects to revolutionize a range of mobile applications. However, the widespread use of NFC is hindered by the fact that only a limited number of platforms have built-in NFC support. Moreover, while NFC's short communication range offers some degree of physical protection, recent findings have revealed NFC's vulnerability to malicious eavesdropping. 

This project develops alternative NFC technologies that are secure and compatible with legacy mobile devices and existing infrastructure (e.g., POS terminals). The key novelty of this approach is to leverage visible light and acoustic channels to realize NFC systems with robust performance and security assurance. Due to the high directionality of narrow light beams, visible light can enable secure and interference-free wireless links. Similarly, acoustic signal can be modulated for NFC communication in close proximity. This approach offers several key advantages over the existing NFC technology. Both visual and acoustic communication channels can be implemented using prevalent components such as LCD displays, microphones, and speakers, which lead to purely software-based solutions that can easily retrofit existing infrastructure with NFC functionality. Second, in contrast to RF channels, the direction and distance of screen-camera link are controllable, preserving the communication privacy and security. Similarly, integrated with physical self-jamming techniques, the acoustic link can achieve information-theoretic security without the need for pre-shared secrets.

In this project, a new form of Visible Light Communication (VLC) is employed to implement NFC, where 2D barcodes are streamed between LCD display and camera. A new barcode design and several techniques are used to optimize the throughput of screen-camera link, which include code block adaptation and re-ordering to mitigate the impact of image blur in mobile environments, and lightweight image processing algorithms for real-time decoding of barcode stream. A systematic security study is conducted on barcode-based communication based on geometric analysis and a new acoustics-based NFC system is developed for smartphones without the need of a priori knowledge of security secrets. The emerging friendly jamming techniques are utilized for establishing an information-theoretically secure communication channel for NFC. This project also explores advanced coding techniques, high-level modulation schemes and other physical layer techniques for further improving the data transmission rates and ensuring confidentiality guarantee.

This project is a multi-disciplinary research effort that integrates novel technologies from visual/acoustic communication, adaptive self-jamming, image processing, and cryptography. The results have impacts on a range of mobile applications such as payment, access control, and smart device paring. The PIs will integrate research results into several courses, and leverage the intriguing nature of the project for reaching out to pre-college students.

por.por_cntn:
Our ﬁrst research module is robust and dependable visual-based NFC. We ﬁrst investigate new forms of visible light communication (VLC) to implement NFC, where 2D barcodes are streamed between LCD display and camera, and conduct systematic security study of the design with physical layer security enhancement mechanisms. Our goal is to design full duplex, energy-eﬃcient communication techniques for barcode streaming NFC systems. Secondly, we investigate and design a novel visual-stimuli-based user authentication framework for smartphone security protection. Speciﬁcally, the proposed technique tracks human eye movement through the built-in from camera and applies the signal processing and pattern matching techniques to explore volitional and non-volitional gaze patterns for access authentication. Four visual stimuli are introduced and discussed in the design and the experiment phases. Through a comprehensive user study, the prototype shows a promising result of applying non-volitional eye response as a biometrics and indicates that it is a secure and usable approach for smartphone user authentication. In addition, We also investigate and design multi-sensors-based system for smartphones, which aims at providing a software-based solution for the communication and eavesdropping between oﬀ-the-shelf smartphones and IoT devices. The developed technique utilizes a speaker, the microphones, and a series sensors on oﬀ-the-shelf smart-phones to achieve concurrent audible and hidden signal detections. Meanwhile, this approach also overcomes the main limitations of existing screen-camera links. We also evaluated it extensively under various environments and practical considerations. The proposed eavesdropping technique against shows its own superiorities in the aspect of the feasibility.

Our second research module is dependable and secure acoustics-based NFC. We investigate and design acoustics-based NFC system for smartphones, which aims at providing a software-based so-lution for the communication between oﬀ-the-shelf smartphones. The developed technique utilizes a speaker and the microphones on oﬀ-the-shelf smartphones to achieve concurrent audible and hidden communication. By leveraging masking eﬀects of the human auditory system and readily available audio signals in the daily lives, it ensures real-time unobtrusive speaker-microphone data commu-nication without aﬀecting the primary audio-hearing experience for human users. Meanwhile, this approach also overcomes the main limitations of existing screen-camera links. We also evaluated it extensively under various environments and practical considerations. The proposed technique shows its own superiorities and can be adopted as a complementary or joint dual-mode communi-cation strategy with existing unobtrusive screen-to-camera communication systems to enhance the system performance under various practical settings.

Our third research module is system prototyping and real-world evaluation. We prototype and test the eﬀectiveness of various proposed designs, evaluate both the eﬃciency and security of the communication performance, and verify and improve the prototypes under real-world conditions. Following this line, we have also explored smartphone-based crowdsourcing systems for building indoor reconstructions. Secondly, We investigate and design a novel visual-stimuli-based user au-thentication framework for smartphone security protection. Speciﬁcally, the proposed technique tracks human eye movement through the built-in from the camera and applies the signal process-ing and pattern matching techniques to explore volitional and non-volitional gaze patterns for access authentication. Four visual stimuli are introduced and discussed in the design and the experiment phases. Through a comprehensive user study, the prototype shows a promising result of applying non-volitional eye response as a biometrics and indicates that it is a secure and usable approach for smartphone user authentication.
